Authors: Torres A.M., Mau-lastovicka T., Vithanage V., Sedgley M.
Title: Segregation distortion and linkage analysis of hand pollinated avocados
Affiliations: Department of Botany, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States; Division of Horticulture, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Merbein, VIC, and Adelaide, SA, 5001, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Torres, A.M., Department of Botany, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States, Division of Horticulture, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Merbein, VIC, and Adelaide, SA, 5001, Australia; Mau-lastovicka, T., Department of Botany, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States, Division of Horticulture, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Merbein, VIC, and Adelaide, SA, 5001, Australia; Vithanage, V., Department of Botany, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States, Division of Horticulture, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Merbein, VIC, and Adelaide, SA, 5001, Australia; Sedgley, M., Department of Botany, University of Kansas, Lawrence, KS 66045, United States, Division of Horticulture, Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organization, Merbein, VIC, and Adelaide, SA, 5001, Australia
Abstract: Various cultivars of avocado (Persea americana MIll.) were hand pollinated to produce 138 seedings in 29 families with from one to 19 progeny. Because the probability of premature fruit drop is normally very high (about 1000 to 1), some of the hand pollinated progeny that abscissed were rescued with embryo culture. Leaf samples of parents and seedlings were assayed for nine genes that specify seven polymorphic enzyme systems-glutamate oxaloacetate transaminase (GOT), leucine aminopeptidase (LAP), malate dehydrogenase (MDH), phosphoglucose Isomerase (PGI), phosphoglucose mutase (PGM), cathodal peroxidase (CPX) and those phosphate isomerase (TPI)-to document the parentage and for further analyses. Families with fewer than four progeny were eliminated from the data sets and several were combined for single-gene segregation and linkage analyses. Some single-gene segregation ratios among the 106 remaining progeny in 10 families were significantly distorted. A linkage analysis indicated that the genes Got1 and Got2 are very tightly linked but those specifying the LAP2, PGI1 and 2, MDH1, PGM1, CPX0 and TPI1 Isozyme sets assorted independently. Eight of the avocado's 12 chromosomes now have Isozyme gene markers. © 1986, American Genetic Association.

Title: Reliability of measurement of open pollinated progeny tests of p. elliottii in South Africa
Affiliations: South African Forestry Research Institute, Pretoria, South Africa
Authors with affiliations: Falkenhagen, E.R., South African Forestry Research Institute, Pretoria, South Africa
Abstract: The distribution properties of the traits assessed in the tree breeding trials of the South African Forestry Research Institute were studied in detail by using three open-pollinated progeny trials of P. elliottii. Over the trials as a whole no trait is distributed normally because the distribution as a whole is a mixture of normal distributions. On a family basis, the growth traits are mostly normally distributed (from 75 to 92 % of the families examined), even average tree volume. The branch characteristics are also mostly distributed normally, including the ratio of branch diameter to stem diameter; the average of two similar traits was distributed more normally than each trait taken individually. Stem form was never distributed normally, but the central limit theorem tells us that the family means for stem form will be sensibly normally distributed. The incidence of butt sweep and forks cannot be submitted to parametric methods of analysis. All traits which could be analysed safely by using parametric methods had no correlations or had very weak ones between their family means and their variances. Therefore no transformation of the basic data would be useful. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Pollination ecology of two nectariferous Cimicifuga sp. (Ranunculaceae) and the evolution of andromonoecy
Affiliations: Dept. of Entomology, Uppsala University, Box 561, Uppsala, S-751 22, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Pellmyr, O., Dept. of Entomology, Uppsala University, Box 561, Uppsala, S-751 22, Sweden
Abstract: The pollination ecology of Cimicifuga americana Michx. and C. laciniata Wats., two nectariferous self?incompatible species, was studied. Both species are pollinated by bumblebees, the former by workers and the latter by males. All bees imbibe nectar and workers also collect pollen, meanwhile performing pollination. Large syrphids act as co?pollinators. C. americana is andromonoecious, and it is suggested that male?flower production at the end of the flowering period contributes a disproportionate fitness component because of dichogamy?induced female?biased functional sex?ratio in the hermaphroditic flowers at that time. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Campbell C.S., Famous N.C., Zuck M.G.
Title: Pollination biology of Primula laurentiana ( Primulaceae) in Maine.
Authors with affiliations: Campbell, C.S.; Famous, N.C.; Zuck, M.G.
Abstract: In E Maine the brightly colored flowers of Primula laurentiana produce no nectar; their faint scent is strongest at the center of the corolla limb in a UV-reflecting, yellow ring. Six species of insects visited the flowers, the most important being the syrphid Helophilus groenlandicus. Since P. laurentiana is self-compatible, long-homostylous, and its stigmas are receptive when the introrse anthers dehisce, pollen-gathering by insects must lead to some self-pollination. This breeding system of facultative autogamy is concordant with the relatively low pollen-ovule ratio of c130 to 1. -from Authors

Title: Insect pollination increases seed production in cruciferous and umbelliferous crops
Affiliations: Laboratory of Animal Behaviour and Simulated Ecology, Department of Zoology, Haryana Agricultural University, Hissar, 125004, India
Authors with affiliations: Sihag, R.C., Laboratory of Animal Behaviour and Simulated Ecology, Department of Zoology, Haryana Agricultural University, Hissar, 125004, India
Abstract: The effect of insect visits on seed production was studied in 9 cruciferous and 4 umbelliferous crop species at Hissar, India, by comparing several yield parameters in open-pollinated plants and plants in cages or with stems bagged. Bees (Apis dorsata, A. florea, A. mellifera and 6 solitary species) were the dominant flower visitors, and were the only species which collected pollen and acted as potential pollinators. Weight of seeds per plant and weight of seeds per ha were significantly greater in open plots of both cruciferous and umbelliferous species than in caged plots. Mean pod (silique) length and numbers of seeds set per pod in open plots of cruciferous plants, and numbers of seeds set per plant in open plots of umbelliferous plants, were significantly greater than in caged plots. Seed size (weight/1000 seeds) was greater in caged plots of umbelliferous plants than in open plots. Per cent seed germination did not differ significantly between treatments. The management of bees for seed production in cruciferous and umbelliferous crop species is recommended. © 1986 International Bee Research Association.

Title: Floral resource sharing by bumblebees and hummingbirds in Pedicularis ( Scrophulariaceae) pollination.
Affiliations: Dept of Entomology, Univ of California, Davis, CA 95616, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Macior, L.W., Dept of Entomology, Univ of California, Davis, CA 95616, USA.
Abstract: Pedicularis densiflora in California was animal pollinator dependent. Younger flowers with short corolla tubes were pollinated by short-tongued Bombus edwardsii workers foraging primarily for nectar, while older flowers with deep tubes were pollinated by nectar-foraging Anna and rufous hummingbirds (Calpyte anna, Selasphorus rufus). Scarlet corollas apparently attract birds, while magenta calyces and floral bracts with highly ultraviolet reflective hairs attract bumblebees. Nectar concentration (sucrose equivalents) varied from 15.0-24.5%; only fructose and sucrose were present. Of corbicular pollen loads from B. edwardsii worker pollinators, 55% contained P. densiflora pollen, and 60% contained pollen of Dodecatheon hendersonii, suggesting that these plants share pollinators by synchronously supplying complementary resources in the same plant community.-from Author

Title: The insect pollinators of Macadamia and their relative importance.
Source title: Journal - Australian Institute of Agricultural Science
Affiliations: CSIRO, Div. of Horticultural Res. Merbein, Victoria 3505, Australia.
Authors with affiliations: Vithanage, V., CSIRO, Div. of Horticultural Res. Merbein, Victoria 3505, Australia.; Ironside, D.A., CSIRO, Div. of Horticultural Res. Merbein, Victoria 3505, Australia.
Abstract: Honey bee Apis mellifera, the lycid beetle Metriorrhynchus rhipidius, the scoliid wasp Campsomeris tasmaniensis and the halictid bee Homalictus sp., play a leading role in macadamia pollination in SW New South Wales. In SE Queensland, the important pollinators are A. mellifera and the apid bee Trigona sp. The latter is probably an important natural pollinator of macadamia, in the rain forests of N New South Wales and SE Queensland, the native habitat of Macadamia sp. -from Authors

Authors: Vences F.J., Vaquero F., Vazquez A.M., Perez De La Vega M.
Title: Isozymatic Changes During in Vitro Morphogenetic Processes in Self-Pollinated Species of Secale
Affiliations: Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad de León, León, 24071, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Vences, F.J., Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Vaquero, F., Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Vazquez, A.M., Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Perez De La Vega, M., Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad de León, León, 24071, Spain
Abstract: The present study was performed to find out the effects on in vitro dedifferentiation and redifferentiation processes on the pattern of several isozymatic systems of self-pollinated Secale species: S silvestre Host. and S. vavilovii Gross. Calluses were obtained from mature embryos cultured in the presence of 2,4-D (2 mg l1), and plant regeneration was induced in a medium without 2,4-D. Isozymatic patterns were studied in coleoptile + mesocotyl emerging from embryos, calluses and shoots regenerated from calluses, and compared with patterns on mature dormant embryo and seedling. Callus formation was very homogeneous in these materials, and a 12 % shoot regeneration was observed in both species. Isozymatic patterns can be clustered into three groups according to the variation in relation to dormant embryo patterns. A clear difference between seedling shoot and callus-regenerated shoot was observed for anodal peroxidases. The remaining isozymatic systems showed variations in their patterns which corresponded to those observed during in vivo germination, or variation in isozyme intensity. These results are briefly discussed in connection with a possible involvement of hormones in isozyme system expression. © 1986, Gustav Fischer Verlag, Stuttgart. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: 2,4-D; 2,4-dichlorophenoxyacetic acid; acid phosphatase; ACP; alkaline phosphatase; ALP; anodal peroxidase; APX; C; callus; callus formation; cathodal peroxidase; CM; coleoptile + mesocotyl; CPX; E + S; embryo + scutellum; glutamic-oxaloacetic transaminase; GOT; isozymes; Linsmaier and Skoog medium; LS; malic dehydrogenase; MDH; PGI; PGM; phosphoglucose isomerase; phosphoglucose mutase; plant regeneration; RE; regenerated shoot; residual embryo; RS; S; Secale silvestre Host; Secale vavilovii Gross; seedling

Title: The influence of wind and animal pollination on variation in outcrossing rates.
Affiliations: Dept. Biology, Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Aide, T.M., Dept. Biology, Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA.
Abstract: Discusses the Lande-Schemske model of the interaction of inbreeding depression and self-fertilization, arguing that an important factor not considered in their survey was the effect of the pollination syndrome. -after Author

Authors: Beardsell D.V., Clements M.A., Hutchinson J.F., Williams E.G.
Title: Pollination of Diuris maculata R Br (Orchidaceae) by floral mimicry of the native legumes Daviesia spp and Pultenaea scabra R. Br.
Affiliations: Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia; Horticultural Research Institute, Knoxfield, P.O. Box 174, Ferntree Gully, VIC, 3156, Australia; Australian National Botanic Gardens, Canberra, P.O. Box 158, Canberra, ACT, 2601, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Beardsell, D.V., Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia, Horticultural Research Institute, Knoxfield, P.O. Box 174, Ferntree Gully, VIC, 3156, Australia; Clements, M.A., Australian National Botanic Gardens, Canberra, P.O. Box 158, Canberra, ACT, 2601, Australia; Hutchinson, J.F., Horticultural Research Institute, Knoxfield, P.O. Box 174, Ferntree Gully, VIC, 3156, Australia; Williams, E.G., Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia
Abstract: Several species of insects captured while feeding on flowers of the legumes Daviesia virgata and D. mimosoides carried pollinia of the orchid Diuris maculata on their heads. In contrast, insects were difficult to capture on Diuris maculata due to the very low frequency and short duration of visits. More pollinaria were removed from the flowers than pollinia deposited. Pollen loads carried by insects bearing orchid pollinia were almost exclusively from Daviesia spp. and Pultenaea scabra. These data, together with the morphological similarity of the flowers of D. maculata to those of Daviesia spp. and Pultenaea scabra, indicate that the orchid attracts pollinators by floral mimicry. © 1986, CSIRO. All rights reserved.

Authors: Williams I.H., Martin A.P., White R.P.
Title: The pollination requirements of oil-seed rape (Brassica napus L.)
Affiliations: Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Williams, I.H., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom; Martin, A.P., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom; White, R.P., Rothamsted Experimental Station, Harpenden, Hertfordshire, United Kingdom
Abstract: The pollination requirements of three cultivars of winter and one of spring swede rape (Brassica napus), grown in a glasshouse, were compared. All cultivars yielded more when hand-pollinated than when auto-pollinated but were self-fertile and yielded equally well whether self or cross-pollinated. In most cultivars plants that were shaken to simulate movement of plants by wind yielded more than auto-pollinated plants and not significantly differently from hand-pollinated plants. Hand-pollinating and shaking plants also increased the set of early flowers. © 1986, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.

Authors: Vences F.J., Vaquero F., Pérez de la Vega M.
Title: Ontogenetic changes in isozyme patterns during seed germination of self-pollinated Secale species
Affiliations: Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad de León, León, E-24071, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Vences, F.J., Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad de León, León, E-24071, Spain; Vaquero, F., Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad de León, León, E-24071, Spain; Pérez de la Vega, M., Departamento de Genética, Facultad de Biología, Universidad de León, León, E-24071, Spain
Abstract: Six isozymatic systems have been studied comparatively during the first week of germination of seeds of self-pollinated Secale species (S. silvestre Host. and S. vavilovii Gross.). Isozymatic systems do not change at all, or reach their definitive adult plant pattern early during germination. © 1986 Birkhäuser Verlag.
Author Keywords: germination; isozyme changes; Secale silvestre; Secale vavilovii; seed

Title: The pollination ecology of two nectarless Cimicifuga sp. (Ranunculaceae) in North America
Affiliations: Dept of Entomology, Uppsala University, Box 561, Uppsala, S-75122, Sweden
Authors with affiliations: Pellmyr, O., Dept of Entomology, Uppsala University, Box 561, Uppsala, S-75122, Sweden
Abstract: The pollination ecology of Cimicifuga rubifolia Kearney and C. elata Nutt., endemic nectarless species in Tennessee and the Pacific Northwest, respectively, was studied. Both species are pollinated by bumblebee workers, which run over the flowers pressing their bodies against them. Large syrphids act as copollinators. Extremely high pollen/ovule ratios are explained as optimal sex allocation in response to pollen?tolling by the pollen?collecting pollinators. Facultative geitonogamy in the self?compatible C. elata seems to be evolved in response to very low pollinator density in the habitat. Because of the pollinator behavior, geitonogamy virtyally always precedes xenogamy. C. rubifolia encounters higher pollinator visit frequency than C. elata, and self?incompatibility prevents selfing. Since it is nectarless, C. rubifolia is inferior in competion for bumblebees with most other entomogamous plants. It appears to have a commensalistic relationship with its constant associates, Impatiens pallida (Balsaminaceae) and/or Polymnia canadensis (Asteraceae), which attract large numbers of bumblebees. C. rubifolia is pollinated by bumblebees encountering them when scouting around the nectar?flower stand. This conclusion is based on: 1) Negative correlation for distance between nectar?flowers and Cimicifuga and the fruit set of the latter, 2) non?skewed flowering period, 3) extremely extended flowering on both the ramet and population levels, only limited by flowering period of nectar?flower associates and by pollinator abundance, and 4) fruit set rates independent of visual display size, and also of flower density in the habitat (i.e., the pollination rate was directly proportional to the density). Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Authors: Crane P.R., Friis E.M., Pedersen K.T.
Title: Lower Cretaceous angiosperm flowers: fossil evidence on early radiation of dicotyledons.
Affiliations: Dept of Geology, Natural History, Roosevelt Road, Chicago, IL 60605, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Crane, P.R., Dept of Geology, Natural History, Roosevelt Road, Chicago, IL 60605, USA.; Friis, E.M., Dept of Geology, Natural History, Roosevelt Road, Chicago, IL 60605, USA.; Pedersen, K.T., Dept of Geology, Natural History, Roosevelt Road, Chicago, IL 60605, USA.
Abstract: Three-dimensionally preserved unisexual angiosperm flowers and inflorescences have been recovered from the Lower Cretaceous Patapsco Formation (Potomac Group) of eastern North America, in sediments approximately 100 million years old. In situ tricolpate pollen shows that the flowers were produced by some of the earliest higher (nonmagnoliid) dicotyledons, and the morphology of pollen, flowers, and inflorescences indicates a close relation to extant Platanaceae. These floral remains suggest that Platanus-like plants with unisexual, probably insect-pollinated flowers were an important element in the mid-Cretaceous diversification of dicotyledonous flowering plants.-from Authors

Title: Reproductive biology of two Florida pawpaws: Asimina obovata and A. pygmaea ( Annonaceae).
Affiliations: Dept of Biology, Stetson Univ, DeLand, FL 32720, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Norman, E.M., Dept of Biology, Stetson Univ, DeLand, FL 32720, USA.; Clayton, D., Dept of Biology, Stetson Univ, DeLand, FL 32720, USA.
Abstract: Both species are strongly protogynous and similar in floral morphology, but different in color and scent. Their flowering periods overlap, but flowering in A. obovata begins at least 2 wk before that of A. pygmaea. Pollinators include large beetles, Trichotinus rufobrunneus, T. lunulatus and Euphoria sepulchralis (Scarabaeidae), which are common to both plant species, and Typocerus zebra (Cerambycidae), which is limited to A. obovata. The beetles prefer flowers in the male phase and consume pollen and corrugated tissue of the inner petals. This tissue is high in carbohydrates with lesser amounts of lipids and proteins. In open-pollinated flowers of A. obovata, 16% set fruits in 1981 and 5.5% in 1982; 32% set fruits in hand-pollinated flowers. Open-pollinated flowers of A. pygmaea yielded fruit-set of 8% in 1981, 8.2% in 1982, and 60% when hand-pollinated. Reciprocal crosses between the two taxa produced fruits in 16% of flowers when A. obovata was the seed parent and 30% when it was the pollen parent.-from Authors

Title: The avoidance of interference between the presentation of pollen and stigmas in angiosperms I. dichogamy
Affiliations: Department of Plant and Microbial Sciences, University of Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand; Botany Division, DSIR, Christchurch, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Lloyd, D.G., Department of Plant and Microbial Sciences, University of Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand, Botany Division, DSIR, Christchurch, New Zealand
Abstract: Dichogamy is the separation of the presentation of pollen and stigmas in time within a plant. It is a common but neglected feature of outcrossing angiosperms. Dichogamy has been almost universally interpreted as an outcrossing mechanism, but many dichogamous species are also self-incompatible (and sometimes also herkogamous and/or with unisexual flowers). In outcrossing species, there is almost invariably a clash between selection to place pollen and stigmas in similar positions for effective pollination and selection to keep the androecia and gynoecia apart to avoid interference between them. We suggest that the separation of pollen and stigmas acts in general to reduce this self-interference and it often also reduces self-fertilisation. Mechanisms preventing self-fertilisation primarily increase maternal fitness, whereas mechanisms avoiding self-interference primarily promote paternal fitness. Five independent ways of subdividing dichogamy are recognised: protandry or protogyny; intrafloral or interfloral dichogamy; complete or incomplete dichogamy; various intervals between the successive presentations of pollen and stigmas; asynchronous, hemisynchronous, or synchronous dichogamy (the latter of several subtypes). In a sample of British species, protandry is almost twice as common as protogyny in biotically pollinated species but protogyny is six times as common as protandry in abiotically pollinated species. To obtain testable hypotheses of the selective forces responsible for dichogamy, four selective forces that influence whether pollen or stigmas are presented first are examined. (1) Effectiveness in avoiding self-fertilisation; (2) Selection for prolonged pollen presentation; (3) Optimal positions for dispatching and receiving pollen; (4) Interference between stamens and carpels, involved in seven different contexts: (a) The relative ease of moving androecia and gynoecia; (b) Vertical wind-pollinated inflorescences; (c) Vertical animal-pollinated inflorescences; (d) Refuge, trap, and brood blossoms; (e) One type of sporophyll facilitates the presentation of the other; (f) Stamen signals or rewards; (g) Post-presentation changes in flowers. The most important factor overall may be the relative ease of moving stamens and carpels after they have functioned. For many species there may be a combination of selective causes of the direction of dichogamy. Besides pollen-stigma interference, other types of interference (in which two activities obstruct each other because they have the same optima) and conflicts (in which two activities have divergent optima) occur in plants. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: British plants; Conflict; Dichogamy; Interference; New Zealand plants; Outcrossing; Pollination; Protandry; Protogyny; Selection

Title: Floral ontogeny of the cashew, Anacardium occidentale L. (Anacardiaceae)
Affiliations: CSIRO Division of Water and Land Resources, G.P.O. Box 1666, Canberra, A.C.T., 2601, Australia; Kamerunga Horticultural Research Station, Queensland, Department of Primary Industries, Redlynch, QLD 4872, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Moncur, M.W., CSIRO Division of Water and Land Resources, G.P.O. Box 1666, Canberra, A.C.T., 2601, Australia; Wait, A.J., Kamerunga Horticultural Research Station, Queensland, Department of Primary Industries, Redlynch, QLD 4872, Australia
Abstract: Scanning electron micrographs of the cashew are presented, showing the development of the male and hermaphrodite inflorescences. An unusual feature is the three different lengths of stamens and their role in pollination. Although cashew flowers have many features common to flowers pollinated by insects, few were observed except for ants. Nectar was not detected in many flowers and concentrations varied between selections. These results are discussed in the light of conflicting views of whether anemophily or entomophily is the basic mode of pollination. © 1986.
Author Keywords: cashew; floral development; nectar; pollination

Title: The evolution of distyly in Primula vulgaris
Source title: Biological Journal of the Linnean Society
Affiliations: University of Sussex, Biology Building, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QG, United Kingdom; Department of Biology, University of Chicago, E 57th Street, Chicago, Illinois, United States
Authors with affiliations: Piper, J., University of Sussex, Biology Building, Falmer, Brighton, BN1 9QG, United Kingdom; Charlesworth, B., Department of Biology, University of Chicago, E 57th Street, Chicago, Illinois, United States
Abstract: Experiments on pollen flow and seed production were performed in populations of P. vulgaris in order to examine the roles of selection for reduced self?pollination in a partially self?fertile morph, selection for reduced stigma clogging, selection for a pollen saving effect, and selection for disassortative pollination in the evolution of morphological distyly (reciprocal herkogamy). Selection for reduced self?pollination and disassortative pollination were shown to have a plausible role in the evolution of this dimorphism. Selection for reduced stigma clogging and pollen saving appeared to have no obvious role in the evolution of morphological distyly. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: disassortative pollination; Distyly; pollen saving; stigma clogging

Title: Floral biology of Myristica fragrans Houtt. (Myristicaceae), the nutmeg of commerce.
Affiliations: Dept of Biological Sciences, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL 61761, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Armstrong, J.E., Dept of Biological Sciences, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL 61761, USA.; Drummond III, B.A., Dept of Biological Sciences, Illinois State Univ, Normal, IL 61761, USA.
Abstract: Staminate flowers are borne in indeterminate inflorescences and function only for a single night. Pistillate flowers are borne solitarily and appear receptive for 2-3 days. Staminate plants may produce >50 times as many flowers as pistillate plants. Both types of flowers are strongly fragrant. A single species of beetle, Formicomus braminus (Anthicidae, ant-mimicking flower beetles), appears to be the best candidate for an effective pollinator of nutmeg in S. India. The beetles are strong fliers, are active nocturnally around staminate flowers, and carry significant pollen loads. Pollen is the only evident pollinator reward. Pistillate flowers produce no reward, and spatial constraints of the perianth and stigma appear to prevent beetles from entering the flowers. Pollen carried on the beetle's head or body would be deposited on the stigma when the insect attempts to enter the flower.-from Authors

Title: The avoidance of interference between the presentation of pollen and stigmas in angiosperms II. herkogamy
Affiliations: Botany Division, DSIR, Christchurch, New Zealand; Department of Plant and Microbial Sciences, University of Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand
Authors with affiliations: Webb, C.J., Botany Division, DSIR, Christchurch, New Zealand; Lloyd, D.G., Department of Plant and Microbial Sciences, University of Canterbury, Christchurch, New Zealand
Abstract: Herkogamy is the spatial separation of pollen presentation and pollen receipt within or between blossoms of an individual plant. Several classes of herkogamy are recognised; these are defined by whether all blossoms are identical (homomorphic herkogamy), all blossoms dispatch and receive pollen but reciprocal forms occur (reciprocal herkogamy), or some or all blossoms perform only one function (interfloral herkogamy). Within homomorphic herkogamy, unordered herkogamy, in which pollinator contacts with stigmas and pollen within a blossom are many and occur in no particular sequence, is distinguished from ordered herkogamy in which contacts are few and ordered. For ordered herkogamy further divisions are based on the operation of the pollination mechanism. Herkogamy is usually interpreted as a mechanism which reduces self-fertilisation and promotes outcrossing. However, as many herkogamous plants are also self-incompatible, it is suggested that the various classes of herkogamy also function in part or solely as mechanisms which avoid interference between pollen receipt by stigmas and pollen dispatch from anthers. Although for herkogamous blossoms these two functions are separated in space, many such flowers control pollinator behaviour so that both pollination surfaces are contacted during a single visit. In dichogamous blossoms separation of pollen dispatch and receipt is temporal rather than spatial and this difference has several important consequences for the pollination biology of dichogamous and herkogamous blossoms. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Dichogamy; Enantiomorphy; Herkogamy; Heterostyly; Monoecism; Outcrossing; Pollenstigma interference; Pollination

Title: Protandry, synchronized flowering and sequential phenotypic unisexuality in neotropical Pentagonia macrophylla (Rubiaceae)
Affiliations: Department of Botany, Duke University, Durham, 27706, NC, United States
Authors with affiliations: McDade, L.A., Department of Botany, Duke University, Durham, 27706, NC, United States
Abstract: The neotropical shrub Pentagonia macrophylla Benth. (Rubiaceae) has protandrous two-day flowers. Synchronous development among flowers on a single individual results in sequential phenotypic unisexuality: the entire plant alternates gender from day to day. Pistillate flowers produce more nectar than staminate flowers at comparable hours, but this difference does not result in different paterns of visitation to male and female flowers by hummingbird pollinators. Rare periods of bisexuality occur due to asynchronous floral development within or between inflorescences and are always followed by return to a synchronized pattern of alternation of gender. Reestablishment of synchrony usually involves a timeframe shift in the pattern of flowering (i.e., a plant produces staminate flowers on days when it previously would have been pistillate). It is suggested that timeframe shifts occur in response to inadequate pollination and serve to either desynchronize the plant from neighboring conspecifics or to temporarily allow self-pollination. © 1986 Springer-Verlag.

Title: Insect visitors to Iris pseudacorus ( Iridaceae) in Ireland.
Affiliations: Dept. Zoology, Univ. College, Cork, Ireland.

Abstract: Insects visiting yellow flag included the syrphid fly Rhingia campestris and the bumblebees Bombus lucorum agg and B. agrorum agg. Comments are made on I. pseudacorus as a food source, and on insect pollination. -P.J.Jarvis

Authors: Williams E.G., Kaul V., Rouse J.L., Palser B.F.
Title: Overgrowth of pollen tubes in embryo sacs of Rhododendron following interspecific pollinations
Affiliations: Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia; School of Physics, University of Xeibourne, Parkviiie, VIC, 3052, Australia; Department of Biological Sciences, Rutgers University, P.O. Box 1059, Piscataway, NJ, 08854, United States
Authors with affiliations: Williams, E.G., Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia; Kaul, V., Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, VIC, 3052, Australia; Rouse, J.L., School of Physics, University of Xeibourne, Parkviiie, VIC, 3052, Australia; Palser, B.F., Department of Biological Sciences, Rutgers University, P.O. Box 1059, Piscataway, NJ, 08854, United States
Abstract: Frequent overgrowths of pollen tubes within the embryo sac are characteristic of a number of interspecific crosses in the genus Rhododendron (Ericaceae). The combined techniques of sectioning, squashing and whole-ovule clearing have confirmed that in ovules showing this phenomenon the pollen tube fails to terminate growth and release sperms on entry into a synergid; instead it continues to grow beyond the synergid and egg cell, often filling the main body of the embryo sac with a coiled and distorted mass. Such ovules fail to develop further. The occurrence and possible causes of this error syndrome are discussed. © 1986, CSIRO. All rights reserved.

Title: Honeyeaters and the pollination biology of Banksia prionotes (proteaceae)
Affiliations: School of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Kent Street, Bentley, WA, 6102, United States
Authors with affiliations: Collins, B.G., School of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Kent Street, Bentley, WA, 6102, United States; Spice, J., School of Biology, Western Australian Institute of Technology, Kent Street, Bentley, WA, 6102, United States
Abstract: Honeyeaters such as Phylidonyris novaehotlandiae and Lichmera indistincta forage preferentially in regions of Banksia prionotes inflorescences where nectar and pollen are most abundant, removing pollen from freshly opened florets and transferring some of it to the stigmatic grooves of other florets on the same or different inflorescences. Each floret is protandrous, with pollen dispersal occurring during the first 4-8 h following initial presentation and significant esterase secretion by the stigma commencing after this phase has ended. Foraging by honeyeaters results in considerable pollen movement between florets on individual trees, although B. prionotes appears to be highly self-incompatible. Movement of honeyeaters and pollen between inflorescences on different trees occurs less frequently than between those on the same trees. Nevertheless, outcrossing leads to penetration of styles by tubes formed by pollen grains deposited in stigmatic grooves in some instances. Despite the small size and isolation of the population studied, the resultant level of follicle formation per infructescence, and percentage seed set, are greater than for most other Banksia species for which data are available. © 1986, CSIRO. All rights reserved.

Title: Performance of plus tree progenies of Pinus contorta originating north of latitude 55oN in a Swedish trial at 64o N.
Affiliations: Dept of Forest Genetics and Plant Physiology, Swedish Univ of Agricultural Sciences, S-901 83 Umea, Sweden.
Authors with affiliations: Fries, A., Dept of Forest Genetics and Plant Physiology, Swedish Univ of Agricultural Sciences, S-901 83 Umea, Sweden.; Lindgren, D., Dept of Forest Genetics and Plant Physiology, Swedish Univ of Agricultural Sciences, S-901 83 Umea, Sweden.
Abstract: Describes a half-sib progeny trial of lodgepole pine in Sweden at 64oN. The progenies originate from open-pollinated plus trees selected from 13 areas in British Columbia and the Yukon. At age 10 yr, condition and height growth differed significantly between areas of origin and between half-sib families. Northern material was healthier and more vigorous and height growth did not vary clinally with latitude. Altitude of origin gave a maximum at 650 m; >800 m, there was a clear decrease in height growth with increasing altitude of origin. Genetic gain by selecting the top 15 parent trees based on 10-yr-old progeny trials was c10% for volume. -from Authors

Title: Cytogenetical studies on African rice, Oryza glaberrima Steud. 2. Autotriploid produced by crossing between autotetraploid and diploid
Affiliations: Laboratory of Genetics and Plant Breeding, College of Agriculture, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka 591, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ishiki, K., Laboratory of Genetics and Plant Breeding, College of Agriculture, University of Osaka Prefecture, Sakai, Osaka 591, Japan
Abstract: Cytogenetical study on the artificial autotriploid of Oryza glaberrima was carried out. The reciprocal crosses between the autotetraploid and the diploid were made to produce the autotriploid. Four (0.05%) autotriploids were obtained only by pollinating the autotetraploid with the pollens of the diploid. As compared with the diploid, the autotriploid increased in stomata length, pollen diameter and length of unhulled and hulled seeds; decreased in number of panicles, pollen stainability, seed fertility and width, thickness and weight of hulled seed. The differences between them were conspicuous in stomata length, pollen diameter, seed fertility and seed weight. The autotriploid had awned spikelets, which was a single character different qualitatively from the diploid. The autotriploid was easily recognized by its seed sterility, but did not show semigigas characteristics so much expected in appearance. In pollen mother cells of the autotriploid, 5 to 12III were observed at the stage of diakinesis to metaphase I, and 12III most frequently. The mean chromosome configuration was 9.20III + 2.68II+3.05I. © 1986, The Genetics Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Title: Ultrastructure et cytochimie des cellules superficielles du micelle de thuya orientalis l (=biota orientalis (l) endl) au moment de lémission de la goutte micropylaire
Source title: Bulletin de la Societe Botanique de France. Lettres Botaniques
Affiliations: Université de Paris VII, Laboratoire des Membranes biologiques, Paris, 75005, France
Authors with affiliations: Seridi, R., Université de Paris VII, Laboratoire des Membranes biologiques, Paris, 75005, France; Chesnoy, L., Université de Paris VII, Laboratoire des Membranes biologiques, Paris, 75005, France
Abstract: During pollination, the nucellus of B. orientals shows two distinct parts: a basal zone with vacuolated cells ensuring the nucellus growth and the differentiation of the sporo- genous tissue, and an upper one formed of starch-containing non vacuolated cells which allow the first stages of the pollen tube development. This part, slightly depressed, is responsable for emission of the pollination drop. The rounded cells bordering the apical depression are separated by large intercellular spaces in contact with the ovular chamber. These cells are of secretory nature. The pla8malemma which shows winding sections is detached from the cell wall. The cytoplasm is dense and contains besides reticulum surrounded amyloplasts, a large number of mitochondria and dictyosomes. The granular reticulum is very conspicuous and ribosomes are abundant. A great number of small Golgi derived vesicles occurs, but their polysaccharidic synthesis is reduced. The activity of the Golgi apparatus seems to be involved in the desorganization of the upper nucellus zone.The entrapping and germination of the pollen grains in B. oriental is ensured by pollination drop. The present data are discussed in light of some current ideas on pollination drop formation in Gymno8perms. © 1986 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Colour and appearance in nature part II. Colour and appearance of flowering plants and animals
Affiliations: Pyghtle Milton Ernest, Bedford, MK44 1RF, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Hutchings, J.B., Pyghtle Milton Ernest, Bedford, MK44 1RF, United Kingdom
Abstract: Colour and appearance of flowering plants and animals are discussed in terms of the three driving forces for colouration discussed in Part I. They are: first, the need to absorb incident radiation; second, the combination of reflection properties and visual characteristics; and third, incidental colouration caused because a biochemical, which has been optimised by an organism, happens to be coloured. Pigments and structures have evolved in both plants and animals to optimise colouration. Many flowering plants have evolved in conjunction with different flying creatures to enable pollination to occur. There are only two principles in animal colouration: Either the animal does not want to be seen or he does want to be seen (or does not mind being seen). The mechanisms by which these aims can be achieved are varied. There are three dimensions to the visual impact, or total appearance, which one animal has upon another: They are colour, pattern, and behavioural display. Copyright © 1986 Wiley Periodicals, Inc., A Wiley Company

Authors: Puertas M.J., Baeza F., Peña A.D.L.
Title: The transmission of b chromosomes in populations of secale cereale and secale vavilovii 1. Offspring obtained from oB and 2B plants
Affiliations: Departamento de Genética, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain
Authors with affiliations: Puertas, M.J., Departamento de Genética, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Baeza, F., Departamento de Genética, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain; Peña, A.D.L., Departamento de Genética, Universidad Complutense, Madrid, 28040, Spain
Abstract: The transmission of rye B chromosomes in experimental populations of Secale cereale and S. vavilovii was studied. B chromosomes were introduced from S. cereale into S. vavilovii by hybridisation and backcrossing. Populations were established with plants carrying OB or 2B chromosomes at different frequencies. Each population was isolated and allowed to fertilise by open pollination. Seeds were collected individually from each OB or 2B plant. The number of B chromosomes in the offspring was analysed. The results showed that there was not a direct relationship between the frequencies at which each type of pollen was formed and the offspring obtained. On the contrary, the effectiveness in fertilisation by pollen with or without B chromosomes was mainly dependent on the frequencies of plants with and without B chromosomes in the population; that is, pollen carrying B chromosomes became relatively more advantageous when its frequency declined. We discuss the proposal that frequency-dependent selection occurs for rye B chromosomes. © 1986 The Genetical Society of Great Britain.

Authors: Brown A.H.D., Grant J.E., Pullen R.
Title: Outcrossing and paternity in Glycine argyrea by paired fruit analysis
Source title: Biological Journal of the Linnean Society
Affiliations: CSIRO Division of Plant Industry, G PO Box 1600, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, 2601, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Brown, A.H.D., CSIRO Division of Plant Industry, G PO Box 1600, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, 2601, Australia; Grant, J.E., CSIRO Division of Plant Industry, G PO Box 1600, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, 2601, Australia; Pullen, R., CSIRO Division of Plant Industry, G PO Box 1600, Canberra, Australian Capital Territory, 2601, Australia
Abstract: Glycine argyrea (Fabaceae), a perennial wild relative of soybean, has a dual flowering strategy of both self?fertilized cleistogamous flowers and chasmogamous flowers on the same plant. Using allozyme polymorphisms the frequency and pattern of outcrossing was determined. The genotypes of seeds from each of several fruit (legumes) per plant were analysed by starch gel electrophoresis, and the maternal genotype inferred. The maximum likelihood estimates of outcrossing rate for the chasmogamous flowers averaged 0.38. The observed level of heterozygosity in the adult population (h = 0.25) compared with the level expected under random mating (h = 0.32) indicated that partial outcrossing was typical of this population. To analyse the mating pattern further, the pollen genotypes of several seeds per legume for pairs of legumes from the same plant were determined. About 35% of fruit from chasmogamous flowers had no genetically detectable outcross progeny, presumably because they were not cross?pollinated effectively. The majority of the remaining fruit had seed which were of mixed origin (both self?fertilized and outcrossed), suggesting that insect pollination does not preclude self?fertilization. As might be expected from this entomophilous pollination system, the pollen of outcrossed seed within one fruit usually (85% of cross?pollinated legumes) came from one male source. Evidence of pollen carry?over was found in the other legumes. The joint distribution of male sources among the pairs of legumes (paired fruit analysis) showed that non?self sources were shared in 30% of pairs. The probability that two outcrossed seeds from the same fruit would be half?sibs was estimated as 0.15, and for two seeds from different fruit on the same plant as 0.42. There is a hierarchy of genetic identity within and among legumes on the same plant, and on different plants, providing scope for the operation of selection at different levels. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Glycine; isozyme; mating system analysis; paternity; self?fertilization

Title: Seasonal changes in the cold tolerance of pitch pine.
Affiliations: Dept of Forestry, Michigan Technological Univ, Houghton, MI 44931, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Berrang, P.C., Dept of Forestry, Michigan Technological Univ, Houghton, MI 44931, USA.; Steiner, K.C., Dept of Forestry, Michigan Technological Univ, Houghton, MI 44931, USA.
Abstract: Pinus rigida stems acclimated more rapidly than secondary needles, but were less cold tolerant in midwinter. Secondary needles and primary needles had similar levels of tolerance on most dates. Strobili and emerging shoots were essentially identical in tolerance except c10 days before pollination, when strobili were 5.8-7.7oC more tolerant than elongating shoots.-from Authors

Title: High-efficiency genetic transformation of maize by a mixture of pollen and exogenous DNA
Source title: Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America
Affiliations: Institute of Agriculture and Forestry, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Ohta, Y., Institute of Agriculture and Forestry, University of Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305, Japan
Abstract: High-efficiency genetic transformation was induced in a genetic stock of maize, Zea mays Linnaeus, by self-pollination of the recipient plants along with DNA of the donor. The highest frequency of transformed endosperm per ear was 9.29%. DNA was applied onto silks in a pollen/DNA pasty mixture. The exogenous DNA transferred into endosperm expressed itself in endosperm formation. It is not known, however, whether the exogenous DNA segment in endosperm had been incorporated or whether it was present in the nucleus additionally, fragmentally, or in some other state. It was rvealed that all of four possible cases had occurred as follows: exogenous DNA was transfrered into (i) both embryo and endosperm of the same kernel, (ii) embryo only, (iii) endosperm only, and (iv) neither embryo nor endosperm. It was also revealed that exogenous DNA that had entered into the embryo had been maintained through embryo formation, germination, vegetative growth and differentiation, and reproductive growth, and finally was manifested in embryo and/or endosperm of the following generation and acted in endosperm formation. The frequency of transformed endosperm in this generation, however, was rather low. It may be that exogenous DNA taken into the embryo was unstable.

Title: Nutrition: Gastronomy, mythology or science?
Affiliations: Honorary Curator for the History, Nutrition at the Medical Center Library, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States
Authors with affiliations: Darby, W.J., Honorary Curator for the History, Nutrition at the Medical Center Library, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN, United States
Abstract: Dr. Joseph Garland was a pediatrician with great appreciation of medical history, a breadth of cultural and humanistic concern and an evident sensitivity to the societal events that shape medical disciplines. His specialty of pediatrics has common roots with the subject of nutrition, roots deep in the rich experiences of history. But only for some two centuries have these subjects been considered fruitful scientific specialities of recognized benefit to mankind. Historically their roots intertwine and many benefits have resulted from cross pollination of the two health species, nutrition and pediatrics. Diseases and pests often affect both, but the subject of Nutrition seems more severely infested, limiting the harvest of its benefits. Therefore analysis of the soil of history and of physiology of the species is in order so that we may reap a greater harvest of benefits distributed to all. But enough of metaphor . © Williams and Wilkins 1986. All Rights Reserved.

Authors: Kaul R.B., Abbe E.C., Abbe L.B.
Title: Reproductive phenology of the oak family ( Fagaceae) in the lowland rain forests of Borneo.
Affiliations: School of Biological Sciences, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE 68588, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Kaul, R.B., School of Biological Sciences, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE 68588, USA.; Abbe, E.C., School of Biological Sciences, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE 68588, USA.; Abbe, L.B., School of Biological Sciences, Univ of Nebraska, Lincoln, NE 68588, USA.
Abstract: Inflorescence primordia were macroscopically visible near the end of the wetter season and anthesis of all flushes occurred in the drier season. There was general synchrony of reproduction among reproducing individuals, but a few trees were sterile throughout the observation period. Some had multiple reproductive flushes at 3-5 wk intervals. Anthesis in the drier season by Castanopsis and Lithocarpus, which are entomophilous, maximizes pollination because that is the season of insect population peaks. Quercus is anemophilous and therefore is unaffected by insect population cycles. -from Authors

Title: Stigmatic pollen loads in populations of Pontederia cordata from the southern US.
Affiliations: Dept of Botany, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, M5S 1A1, Canada.
Authors with affiliations: Glover, D.E., Dept of Botany, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, M5S 1A1, Canada.; Barrett, S.C.H., Dept of Botany, Univ of Toronto, Toronto, Ontario, M5S 1A1, Canada.
Abstract: The long-styled morph usually experiences legitimate pollination, whereas the mid-styled and short-styled morphs often display random pollination. Thus tristyly may have only a minor influence of the fecundity of morphs. In clonal species, such as Pontederia cordata, where geitonogamous pollinations are promoted by large floral displays, floral mechanisms that increase pollen carryover may have selective value. -from Authors

Title: POPULATION COMPOSITION, GENDER SPECIALIZATION, AND THE ADAPTIVE SIGNIFICANCE OF DISTYLY IN LINUM PERENNE (LINACEAE)
Affiliations: Institut für Systematische Botanik, Universität Zürich, Zollikerstrasse 107, Zürich, CH-8008, Switzerland
Authors with affiliations: NICHOLLS, M.S., Institut für Systematische Botanik, Universität Zürich, Zollikerstrasse 107, Zürich, CH-8008, Switzerland
Abstract: Spatial distribution, pollen?flow and the factors affecting seed?set were studied for a population of the distylous perennial Linum perenne L. during a single season. The morphs were spatially segregated at the site. Stigmatic pollen loads on long?style plants comprised 27 to 51 % legitimate pollen and on short?style plants 0 to 46% legitimate pollen. Most flowers received more legitimate pollen grains than the number theoretically required to fertilize the corresponding number of ovules. Intraflower pollinations accounted for a large proportion of individual stigma loads. There was a weak negative correlation between the distance of the nearest legitimate neighbour and the number of legitimate pollen grains recorded on the stigma. No relationship was established between either the proximity or proportion of legitimate neighbours and seed?set. Long?style plants produced less pollen and matured more seeds than short?style plants. It is suggested that, in the population studied, paternal (pollen) and maternal (seed) investment are unequally divided between the morphs. This may be a common theme associated with heterostyly in plants. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: gender specialization; heterostyly; Linaceae; Linum perenne L; pollen?flow

Title: Thigmomorphogenesis: Anatomical, morphological and mechanical analysis of genetically different sibs of Pinus taeda in response to mechanical perturbation
Affiliations: Lab. of Tree-Ring Research, Univ. of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona, 85721, United States; Biology Dept, Wake Forest Univ, Winston-Salem, North Carolina, 27109, United States
Authors with affiliations: Telewski, F.W., Lab. of Tree-Ring Research, Univ. of Arizona, Tucson, Arizona, 85721, United States; Jaffe, M.J., Biology Dept, Wake Forest Univ, Winston-Salem, North Carolina, 27109, United States
Abstract: Twenty?three open pollinated families (half?sibs) and four controlled pollinated families (full?sibs) of Pinus taeda L. (loblolly pine) were grown in a greenhouse and analyzed for changes induced by mechanical perturbation (MP). These changes included inhibition of stem and needle elongation, bracing of branch nodes, and increased radial growth in the direction of the MP. Inhibition of stem elongation was the least variable feature measured. Leaf extension and stem diameter were highly variable between half?sibs. MP induced increased drag in greenhouse grown P. taeda in wind?tunnel tests. In P. taeda, MP induced decreased flexibility and increased elasticity and plasticity of the stem. The increased radial growth of the stems overrode the increase in elasticity, resulting in an overall decrease in flexibility. MP trees had a higher rupture point than non?MP controls. Increased radial growth is a result of more rapid cell divisions of the vascular cambium, resulting in increased numbers of tracheids. The decreased leader growth is partly due to a decreased tracheid length in response to MP. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Drag; elasticity; flexural stiffness; full?sib; half?sib; plasticity; wind; wood anatomy

Authors: Dutta M., Bandyopadhyay A., Arunachalam V., Kaul S.L., Prasad M.V.R.
Title: Radiation induced pollen sterility and enhanced outcrossing in groundnut (Arachis hypogaea L.)
Affiliations: Indian Agricultural Research Institute, Regional Station, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500030, India; Groundnut Improvement Programme, ICRISAT, Patancheru P.O., Andra Pradesh 502324, India
Authors with affiliations: Dutta, M., Groundnut Improvement Programme, ICRISAT, Patancheru P.O., Andra Pradesh 502324, India; Bandyopadhyay, A., Indian Agricultural Research Institute, Regional Station, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500030, India; Arunachalam, V., Indian Agricultural Research Institute, Regional Station, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500030, India; Kaul, S.L., Indian Agricultural Research Institute, Regional Station, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500030, India; Prasad, M.V.R., Indian Agricultural Research Institute, Regional Station, Rajendranagar, Hyderabad, 500030, India
Abstract: Seeds of six groundnut cultivars with distinguishable morphological features were irradiated with 5, 10, 15 and 20 kR gamma rays and grown surrounded by a pollen parent. The effect of irradiation on pollen sterility and other quantitative characters was studied in M1. Pollen sterility increased almost linearly with increase in dose in each cultivar. There was significant variety × dose interaction. The correlation between inherent pollen sterility (measured in control) and percent increase in sterility was negative. The induced variation was significant only for five quantitative characters. Fifteen kR was the most effective dose for inducing a high level of pollen sterility without causing significant change in other characters. The correlation between pollen sterility and cross-pollination % was positive and significant implying that induced pollen sterility would enhance cross-pollination. © 1986.

Authors: Uchino A., Miyazaki T., Miyazaki T.
Title: Recovery of a SAT-chromosome a2 incurred differential amphiplasty in amphidiploids of Scilla scilloides Druce
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860, Japan; Department of Oral Histology, Nagasaki University School of Dentistry, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Uchino, A., Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860, Japan; Miyazaki, T., Department of Biology, Faculty of Science, Kumamoto University, Kumamoto 860, Japan; Miyazaki, T., Department of Oral Histology, Nagasaki University School of Dentistry, Japan
Abstract: Chromosome constitution was analyzed in progenies from the translocation heterozygous allotetraploids (2n=34, AATBBT) of Scilla scilloides Druce. Fifteen plants out of 139 selfed and 25 open-pollinated progenies were homo-or heterozygous for the chromosome a2s carrying a large satellite, though the parental plants had no satellited a2. This SAT-chromosome is similar to satellited a2 present in the Korean diploid AA but not to non-satellited a2 found in allopolyploids. Thus satellited a2 which incurred differential amphiplasty may possibly have recovered its normal shape in the allotetraploids. Diploid AA comprising satellited a2 may possibly contribute to the synthesis of allopolyploids. © 1986, The Genetics Society of Japan. All rights reserved.

Title: Comparative reproductive biology of alpine biennial and perennial gentians ( Gentiana: Gentianaceae) in California.
Affiliations: Dept. of Botany, Univ. of California, Berkeley, California 94720, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Spira, T.P., Dept. of Botany, Univ. of California, Berkeley, California 94720, USA.; Pollak, O.D., Dept. of Botany, Univ. of California, Berkeley, California 94720, USA.
Abstract: High fruit and seed set and production of a relatively large number of seeds characterized the alpine biennials, Gentiana tenella and G. prostrata; fruit and seed set were considerably reduced and yearly seed production was relatively low in the alpine perennial, G. newberryi. Successful seed production in the biennial species was a result of low rates of flower predation, self-pollination, and the allocation of a comparatively high proportion of biomass to reproductive structures. Seed production in the perennial species was limited by high rates of flower predation, insufficient amounts of pollen reaching stigmas, an unusually late flowering period, and by the relatively small proportion of biomass allocated to reproduction. -from Authors

Title: The Mu transposable elements of maize: evidence for transposition and copy number regulation during development.
Authors with affiliations: Alleman, M.; Freeling, M.
Abstract: The Mu transposon of maize exists in a highly mutagenic strain called Robertson's Mutator. Plants of this strain contain 10-50 copies of the Mu element, whereas most maize strains and other plants have none. When Mutator plants are crossed to plants of the inbred line 1S2P, which does not have copies of Mu, the progeny plants have approximately the same number of Mu sequences as did their Mutator parent. Approximately one-half of these copies have segregated from their parent and one-half have arisen by transposition and are integrated into new positions in the genome. This maintenance of copy number can be accounted for by an extremely high rate of transposition of the Mu elements (10-15 transpositions per gamete per generation). When Mutator plants are self-pollinated, the progeny double their Mu copy number in the first generation, but maintain a constant number of Mu sequences with subsequent self-pollinations. Transposition of Mu and the events that lead to copy number maintenance occur very late in the development of the germ cells but before fertilization. A larger version of the Mu element transposes but is not necessary for transposition of the Mu sequences. The progeny of crosses with a Mutator plant occasionally lack Mutator activity; these strains retain copies of the Mu element, but these elements no longer transpose.

Title: The Response of Viviparous-1 and Wild Type Embryos of Zea mays to Culture in the Presence of Abscisic Acid
Affiliations: Department of Biology, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, 06 520, United States
Authors with affiliations: Robichaud, C., Department of Biology, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, 06 520, United States; Sussex, I.M., Department of Biology, Yale University, New Haven, Connecticut, 06 520, United States
Abstract: Embryos of the viviparous-1 (vp1) mutant of Zea mays do not enter developmental arrest, but germinate precociously, becoming seedlings while still attached to the ear. Studies with excised embryos show that when immature embryos of both vp1 and normal maize are cultured for 7d in the presence of a range of concentrations of abscisic acid (ABA), the mutant expresses a reduced sensitivity to the inhibitory effects of ABA. In addition, length measurements recorded throughout the culture period demonstrate that normal embryos are as competent to germinate precociously as vp1 embryos, and that the differences in sensitivity to ABA arise as a consequence of alterations in both rate of growth and time of germination. © 1987, Gustav Fisher Verlag, Stuttgart. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: ABA; abscisic acid; Abscisic acid Embryo culture; DAP; days after pollination; Vivipary; Zea

Authors: Barden K.A., Smith S.S., Murakishi H.H.
Title: Regeneration and screening of tomato somaclones for resistance to tobacco mosaic virus
Affiliations: Department of Botany and Plant Pathology, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1312, United States
Authors with affiliations: Barden, K.A., Department of Botany and Plant Pathology, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1312, United States; Smith, S.S., Department of Botany and Plant Pathology, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1312, United States; Murakishi, H.H., Department of Botany and Plant Pathology, Michigan State University, East Lansing, MI 48824-1312, United States
Abstract: Leaf discs of tomato (Lycopersicon esculentum, Mill.) from a fully tobacco mosaic virus (TMV)-susceptible (+/+) isogenic line, GCRI-26 (Glasshouse Crops Research Institute, Littlehampton, U.K.), were used to regenerate somaclones (Sc). Out of 370 somaclones inoculated with TMV-Flavum, six wereeventually selected as virus-free and putatively resistant. R1 progeny from self-pollination of the six somaclones showed TMV-resistance for varying periods ranging from 28 to 55 days (extent of test) while seedlings of the source plant usually became infected in 10-20 days. In resistant plants, no symptoms were visible and TMV could not be detected either by enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) or by back inoculations to Nicotiana glutinosa. © 1986.
Author Keywords: Lycopersicon esculentum; mosaic virus resistance; somaclonal variation; tomato

Title: Primary and Secondary Direct Somatic Embryogenesis from Immature Zygotic Embryos of Brassica campestris
Affiliations: Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Victoria, 3052, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Maheswaran, G., Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Victoria, 3052, Australia; Williams, E.G., Plant Cell Biology Research Centre, School of Botany, University of Melbourne, Parkville, Victoria, 3052, Australia
Abstract: Somatic embryoids have been induced directly from superficial cells of the lower hypocotyl of immature sexual embryos of Brassica campestris. The response was specific to a limited period of embryonic development, but occurred on 10 of a total of 18 media tested, involving three different basal media, presence or absence of yeast extract and three hormone regimes. For one medium (B5 plus 0.05 mg · 1?1 BAP) a spontaneous secondary cycle of direct somatic embryogenesis occurred, giving a final embryo multiplication factor of better than 150. Embryoids could be readily rooted and transferred to soil. Conditions leading to direct hypocotyl embryogenesis are discussed. The most important factor appears to be internal pre-embryogenic determined state of initiating cells. The system offers a means for minimising pollinations in the maintenance of self-incompatible inbred lines of B. campestris. Key words © 1986, Gustav Fischer Verlag, Stuttgart. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Brassica campestris; embryo culture; Somatic embryogenesis; tissue culture

Title: Organelle Transfer
Authors with affiliations: Galun, E.; Aviv, D.
Abstract: This chapter discusses the procedures that specifically involve organelle transfer or organelle-controlled traits and reviews the techniques for isolation, culture, fusion of protoplasts and plant regeneration from cultured protoplasts. Organelle transmission in most of the higher plants is uniparental. Thus, chloroplasts and mitochondria are transmitted together, maternally, irrespective of if the plants are self- or cross-pollinated. Transfer of heritable traits by conventional genetic manipulation, as practiced for nuclear genes, is therefore not applicable to organelle genes. To facilitate the construction of a plant having in its cells a given nuclear genome but chloroplast and/or mitochondria from another plant, a donor-recipient fusion should be performed. The cybrid plants, derived from such a fusion, should result from a Recipient protoplast where the original functional nucleus is retained, but either one or both of the cytoplasmic organellesthat is, chloroplasts and mitochondriais exchanged by organelles from a Donor plant. © 1986, Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved.

Title: Floral Viability and Pollen Tube Growth in Vicia faba L.
Affiliations: Plant Breeding Institute, Maris Lane, Trumpington, Cambridge, CB2 2LQ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stoddard, F.L., Plant Breeding Institute, Maris Lane, Trumpington, Cambridge, CB2 2LQ, United Kingdom
Abstract: Durations of stigmatic receptivity, pollen viability and pollen tube growth were investigated in the largely entomophilous faba bean. Stigmas were examined for deposited and germinated pollen, and growth of pollen tubes was investigated using aniline blue-induced fluorescence. Entry of a pollen tube into a micropyle was found to be a reliable indicator of fertilization. After anthesis, stigmas remained receptive to pollination for six days, and pollen viable for five. Pollen tubes took up to three days to reach the ovules furthest from the stigma. Inspection of ovular development within pods showed that the incidence of fertilization had been accurately determined in the flowers. © 1986, Gustav Fischer Verlag, Stuttgart. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: fertilization; Leguminosae; pollen tube growth; pollen viability; stigmatic receptivity; Vicia faba L.

Authors: Mazer S.J., Snow A.A., Stanton M.L.
Title: Fertilization dynamics and parental effects upon fruit development in Raphanus raphanistrum: consequences for seed size variation.
Affiliations: Dept of Botany, Univ of California at Davis, Davis, California 95616, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Mazer, S.J., Dept of Botany, Univ of California at Davis, Davis, California 95616, USA.; Snow, A.A., Dept of Botany, Univ of California at Davis, Davis, California 95616, USA.; Stanton, M.L., Dept of Botany, Univ of California at Davis, Davis, California 95616, USA.
Abstract: In wild radish 97% of the variation in mean seed wt per fruit was explained by an analysis of variance incorporating parental effects, pollination date, and the number of seeds per fruit. Strong maternal effects are documented on number of ovules per ovary, number of fertilized ovules per ovary, number of seeds per fruit, and mean individual seed wt per fruit. -from Authors

Title: Life history studies of Conopholis americana ( Orobanchaceae).
Affiliations: Biol Dept, Gilmer Hall, Univ of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA 22901, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Baird, W.V., Biol Dept, Gilmer Hall, Univ of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA 22901, USA.; Riopel, J.L., Biol Dept, Gilmer Hall, Univ of Virginia, Charlottesville, VA 22901, USA.
Abstract: Squawroot is a perennial obligate parasite which attaches to the roots of its oak host. The plant body is subterranean, with only the annual flowering stalks appearing aboveground. Squawroot lives an average of 9-10yr and flowers in 4yr. Following onset of senescence, a deterioration phase typically of no more than 2yr preceded death. Pollination appeared to be predominantly autogamous. Long distance dispersal of the seeds was facilitated by mammals, especially deer. Seed viability was high (55%). Germination induced in the laboratory was low (3%), though comparable to the germination level (1%) of seeds in soil samples. The critical factor in germination and seedling establishment was the oak-mycorrhizal association which was preferentially attacked.-from Authors

Title: TREATMENT OF THE STIGMA WITH AN EXTRACT OF A COMPATIBLE PISTIL OVERCOMES SELF?INCOMPATIBILITY IN PETUNIA
Affiliations: Department of Botany, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110007, India
Authors with affiliations: SHARMA, N., Department of Botany, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110007, India; SHIVANNA, K.R., Department of Botany, University of Delhi, Delhi, 110007, India
Abstract: Treatment of the stigma with an extract of a compatible pistil, just before pollination, was very effective in overcoming self?incompatibility in Petunia hybrida Vilm. Progressive delay either in the application of the extract, or in pollination markedly reduced its efficacy in overcoming self?incompatibility? The treatment seems to mask the self?incompatibility recognition molecules of the pistil. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: Petunia hybrida; pollen recognition; self?incompatibility

Title: Patterns of fruit-set: what controls fruit-flower ratios in plants?
Affiliations: Dept. of Biology, Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA.
Authors with affiliations: Sutherland, S., Dept. of Biology, Univ. of Utah, Salt Lake City, UT 84112, USA.
Abstract: Fruit-set values for 447 species of plants were examined for variations due to compatibility, breeding system, life form, latitude, type of fruit, and type of pollination. Results indicate significant differences between self-compatible and self-incompatible species in terms of 1) average fruit-set and 2) the effect of the independent variables. Breeding system, life form, and latitude were the only significant independent variables for self-incompatible species; fruit type and latitude were found to be significant for self-compatible plants. Selective-abortion and bet-hedging hypotheses may be important factors contributing to the low fruit-set in self-incompatible plants, while the male-function hypothesis may explain the lower fruit-flower ratios in hermaphrodites. -from Author

Authors: Barendse G.W.M., Kepczynski J., Karssen C.M., Koornneef M.
Title: The role of endogenous gibberellins during fruit and seed development: Studies on gibberellin?deficient genotypes of Arabidopsis thaliana
Affiliations: Dept of Botany, Univ. of Nijmegen, Toernooi veld, Nijmegen, 6525 ED, Netherlands; Research Institute of Pomology and Floriculture, Skierniewice, 96-100, Poland; Dept of Plant Physiology, Agricultural Univ, Arboretumlaan 4, Wageningen, 6703 BD, Netherlands; Dept of Genetics, Agricultural Univ, Generaal Fouikesweg 53, Wageningen, 6703 BM, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Barendse, G.W.M., Dept of Botany, Univ. of Nijmegen, Toernooi veld, Nijmegen, 6525 ED, Netherlands; Kepczynski, J., Research Institute of Pomology and Floriculture, Skierniewice, 96-100, Poland; Karssen, C.M., Dept of Plant Physiology, Agricultural Univ, Arboretumlaan 4, Wageningen, 6703 BD, Netherlands; Koornneef, M., Dept of Genetics, Agricultural Univ, Generaal Fouikesweg 53, Wageningen, 6703 BM, Netherlands
Abstract: Siliqua development was studied in the wild type line Landsberg erecta and the GA?sensitive mutant ga?1 of Arabidopsis thaliana (L.) Heynh. Reciprocal crosses between wild type and ga?l mutant, and self pollinations of either parent have shown that siliqua growth is determined by endogenous GAs originating from maternal tissues and embryo. The ga?1 mutant either self pollinated or cross?pollinated with wild type pollen showed reduced siliqua growth, which to a large extent could be overcome by exogenously applied GAs. The siliquae of the ga?1 mutant possessed very reduced ent?kaurene synthesizing capacity and no detectable endogenous GA?activity indicating an early block in the GA?biosynthetic pathway. Seed weight is not affected by GA?deficiency during development. Copyright © 1986, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved
Author Keywords: ent kaurene; gibberellin biosynthesis

Title: Use of vital dyes in conjunction with the semivitro technic for the detection of pollen tube sperm nuclei
Affiliations: Department of Botany, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Mulcahy, G.B., Department of Botany, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States; Mulcahy, D.L., Department of Botany, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, MA, United States
Abstract: The technique we describe here is a modification of that used by Hough et al. (1985), combined with "semivitro" pollen tube observations. With the semivitro technique, pollen tubes grow from the cut ends of pollinated styles (Brewbaker and Majumder 1961). Pollen of Nicotiana alata was presoaked for 15 min in simplified medium (Brewbaker and Kwack 1963) (10% sucrose, 300 ppm Ca(NO3)2, 100 ppm H3BO3 with the addition of 0.5 mg/ml of Hoechst 33258 stain from Serva Biochemicals, Heidelberg, Control H, purchased June 1983). (For germination of Nicotiana alata pollen in vitro, we use this same solution, except with 12% sucrose). After this prestaining, the pollen suspension was centrifuged for 5 min at 1200 × g, the pellet resuspended in control Brewbaker medium (i.e., no stain), recentrifuged and used to pollinate detached pistils. The pistils were then incubated at 25 C in a water-saturated atmosphere for 20 hr. At this time, the styles were cut just ahead of the front of the growing pollen tubes (Mulcahy and Mulcahy 1985) and the cut stylar ends each dipped in fresh control Brewbaker medium. Twelve to 24 hours later, tubes growing out of the cut styles were viewed by fluorescence microscopy (exciter filter, BG 12 + KV 418, beam splitter, 500 nm, and barrier filter OG 515). A distinct green fluorescence was seen in the generative and vegetative nuclei (Fig. 1). © 1986 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.

Authors: Reid M.J., Moss R.B., Hsu Y.-P., Kwasnicki J.M., Commerford T.M., Nelson B.L.
Title: Seasonal asthma in northern California: Allergic causes and efficacy of immunotherapy
Source title: The Journal of Allergy and Clinical Immunology
Affiliations: Allergy Clinic, David Grant Medical Center, Travis Air Force Base, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Reid, M.J., Allergy Clinic, David Grant Medical Center, Travis Air Force Base, CA, United States, ; Moss, R.B., Allergy Clinic, David Grant Medical Center, Travis Air Force Base, CA, United States, ; Hsu, Y.-P., Allergy Clinic, David Grant Medical Center, Travis Air Force Base, CA, United States, ; Kwasnicki, J.M., Allergy Clinic, David Grant Medical Center, Travis Air Force Base, CA, United States, ; Commerford, T.M., Allergy Clinic, David Grant Medical Center, Travis Air Force Base, CA, United States, ; Nelson, B.L., Allergy Clinic, David Grant Medical Center, Travis Air Force Base, CA, United States,
Abstract: Inland areas of northern California have an intense grass pollination in the spring of each year. This is accompanied by a stirking rise in the incidence of asthma. We documented this relationship and designed a trial to test the efficacy of immunotherapy for grass-pollen asthma. Aeroallergen counts were performed on the roof of the allergy clinic of David Grant Medical Center from January 1981 to December 1984 by a gravity collector. These counts were compared to counts done on a Rotorod at a nearby hospital from July 1982 to September 1984. Climatologic factors were also tabulated. Visits for asthma and rhinitis to our emergency room and asthma admissions to our hospital were counted for the 4-year period. A randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled trial of immunotherapy with grass-pollen extract was performed from November 1984 to June 1985. Two groups of clinically and immunologically well-matched subjects were started on an accelerated preseasonal trial of immunotherapy. One group received a standardized grass extract, and the other group did not. Both groups received other extracts of aeroallergens to which they were skin test positive that occur locally in the spring and summer. This was done because of our dissatisfaction with a histamine placebo used in a previous pilot study. Symptom medication scores (SMS) and immunologic parameters were followed. For the 4-year period, grass-pollen count (GPC) correlated strongly with asthma emergency room visits (r = 0.90; p < 0.001) and for rhinitis (r = 0.92; p < 0.001). Asthma admissions also correlated strongly with GPC (r = 0.72; p < 0.001). Other aeroallergens either did not correlate significantly or occurred in such small numbers that they could not be seriously considered. Rotorod counts supported these conclusions with the exceptions of some Basidiomycetes. Climatologic factors demonstrated no relationship to the incidence of asthma. Asthma SMS were lower in the grass-treated group, p < 0.05. Rhinitis SMS were also lower but did not reach significance, p = 0.11. RGGI sIgE did not rise significantly in the grass-treated group but did in the placebo-treated group. RGGI sIgG rose in both groups, although to significantly higher levels in the grass-treated group, p < 0.001. The asthma SMS were inversely related to increasing RGGI cumulative dose, p < 0.10. Linear regression analysis of the dose-response scattergram suggests that a cumulative dose of approximately 90 ?g of RGGI may be desirable.
